sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Hello and welcome to Euronews tonight. Here are our top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: No surrender. Ukraine rejects Russia's offer to open corridors out of Mariupol in return for the capitulation of its defenders, as remaining residents fight for their survival.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: No new sanctions. European Union foreign ministers accuse Russia's military of committing war crimes in Ukraine, but they appear unlikely to impose a fifth round of punishments.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Here in the Cube, we'll be looking at claims falsely linking the Ukrainian president to the Nazi regime.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And no mincing of words.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Nazanin Zaghari-Radcliffe lashes out at the British government for the six-year delay in getting her out of an iranian jail welcome to the program i'm stefan grober a city left in devastation fears that a huge humanitarian crisis is unfolding as almost 350 000 people remain trapped without water and electricity in the ukrainian port city of mariopol residents have been subject to almost a month of bombardment by russian forces efforts to evacuate civilians from mariopol are ongoing after ukraine rejected a russian ultimatum to surrender early on monday morning Local officials say around a thousand people have already been forcibly transported to Russia-controlled territory and stripped of their Ukrainian passports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, Ukrainian authorities say the first attack on Odessa on the Black Sea has hit residential buildings.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: However, Russia denies targeting civilians.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: In Kyiv, eight people have died after a shopping mall was hit late on Sunday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: But officials warned that that figure is likely to rise.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Russia claims they bombed the center because it was being used to store rocket systems.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: The Ukrainian capital continues to be bombarded, but Russia has so far failed to take control.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: The city's mayor, Vitaly Klitschko, warned residents that the shelling is polluting the air.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Vitaly Klitschko, Mayor of Kiev, Due to fires after the airstrikes in the capital and the region, air pollution has been detected.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: So do not open windows.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And when you go outside, protect your lungs by wearing a medical mask.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Type FFP2. wearing a medical mask type ffp2 i appeal to the residents of kiev do not film or post videos of the movement of military equipment checkpoints or strategic objectives joining me now from the beleaguered ukrainian capital of kiev is our international correspondent Don't help the city.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: I'm right now by Maidan, which is a symbolic square in the heart of Kyiv.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And we kept hearing some what sounded like gunfire not very far away.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: It has been a very difficult day for Kyiv, for the Ukrainian capital.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: As you mentioned, at least eight people have been killed when that residential area was shelled.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Russia saying it was targeting an ammunition depot, but Ukrainian authorities denying that information, saying that that was a purely residential district, like several others that have been hit over the last few days. Several people, at least six people, have been killed in Kyiv over the last week, and now, of course, today, this deadly attack. Many of the residents there were absolutely shocked, very, very sad. But there's also a growing sense of anger here in Kiev, anger at Russia for starting this war, but also anger at the West for not doing enough to stop Moscow's offensive here in Ukraine. Earlier today, we went to a cemetery and got to witness a burial.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: A very bereaved family was burying their father, whose body it took them a month to retrieve.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: He died in the battlefield near the city of Irpin.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And his son Artem told me that he has no other choice now but to join the war to take revenge for his father.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: We didn't start it, but we will finish it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Russians can't fight in close combat.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Just remember that they are commies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Do you hear this right now?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: This is a rinse and this means that they again start bombing us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Alice, I want to ask you about Mariupol.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: We are hearing that Port City is at the brink of a humanitarian catastrophe, yet the Ukrainians have rejected a ceasefire proposed by the Russians.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Why is that?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: A ceasefire proposed by the Russians. Why is that?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Well, the Ukrainians say they are not going to lay down their weapons.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: They say they are not going to hand over any territory to Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: The message here has been one very clear over the last few weeks, is that they are in their territory, they are in their land and then they have the right to defend it. But you're right, Mariupol has suffered perhaps the most in these three weeks of fighting. It has now been almost completely besieged and it has been shelled repeatedly over the last few weeks. The mayor of that city describing 80 percent of the infrastructure there of buildings there being damaged many beyond repair and of course the civilians that have been able to flee mariupol describe hellish living conditions no water no electricity no food and of course they are risking their lives to try and escape that scenario because many of the humanitarian corridors over the last few days and weeks have been shelled at. So a very difficult situation. Of course we've heard from those two latest shelling of a theater and then an art school emergency responders still trying to get bodies or survivors out of the debris, but saying that the constant shelling has not helped the work and the rescue operations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So a very difficult situation indeed for the port city of Mariupol, a strategic point for Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Many analysts saying that they would like to keep that corridor from the east of the country all the way to Crimea. And of course, that includes Mariupol, which would of course, completely block Ukraine from accessing the Azov Sea. All right, Annelies Borges, our international correspondent from the Ukrainian capital. Thank you very much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: EU foreign and defense ministers have been holding crisis talks in Brussels today to discuss a possible fifth round of sanctions on Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: They've been debating yet more restrictive measures aimed at paralysing Moscow's war efforts in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Some member states are seeking tougher sanctions that target Russia's lucrative oil and gas exports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: But others, such as Germany, are opposed to strict embargoes. are seeking tougher sanctions that target Russia's lucrative oil and gas exports. But others, such as Germany, are opposed to strict embargoes. Europe relies on Russia for 40% of its gas. But in a video message, Ukraine's President Zelenskyy pleaded with governments to cut ties with Moscow.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Please do not sponsor Russia's military machine, nor give a single euro to these occupiers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Close your ports to them. Don't import goods. Say no to Russian energy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Do everything for Russia to leave Ukrainian soil.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: I believe and I know that peace is possible, but you have to act to bring the peace.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Let's bring in our correspondent in Brussels, Shona Murray.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Shona, good evening and good to see you. So discussions about further sanctions on Russia's energy sector are sure to divide opinion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Where do the fault lines lie on the subject here?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Well, you mentioned it there, Stefan.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: We know that some countries, Poland and the Baltics, would like to see the EU going much, much further to paralyse the Russian economy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And a total trade ban Poland is calling for, in addition, a banning in the short term on the reliance on Russian gas, oil, coal.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Other countries, however, Germany, Austria, Italy, Hungary, for example, would like to see the fifth round of sanctions to be much more measured, that there will be a consolidation about what's already been done, but also would really hope to protect the EU's economies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Because, of course, you mentioned there the EU relies on Russia for over 40% of its gas in particular.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So those countries are very reticent around that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So that issue of sanctions will very much feature, is featuring, as we note, on today's huge summit of foreign affairs ministers. There won't be any major decisions made today, but it will be brought forward, the discussion for the next few days when EU leaders meet here on Thursday, who will be joined by US President Joe Biden.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: The EU's top diplomat, Josep Borre, has accused Russia of committing a massive war crime in Mariupol.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Is that a consensus among the foreign ministers?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Because there's a very, very strict definition when it comes to war crime.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Well, there is, of course.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: There's a consensus that on the face of it, Russia is committing war crimes in Russia, in Mariupol in particular, because there's clear, as far as ministers and other lawyers, the US and others are concerned, there's clear use of starvation as a method of trying to get the population there to move out of Mariupol, the use of indiscriminate shooting from the Russian army, not only that, but the targeting of civilians, all of these issues that are mentioned on the face of it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Of course, we know that there is cold and there will be an international criminal court investigation into war crimes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But when you look at what's happening in Russia, the disproportionate use of force, many people can see that these are grave breaches of the Geneva Conventions and then are therefore war crimes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Shona, Ministers are also set to discuss the Global Compass, the Bloc's new Strategic Compass.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: I'm sorry, what does this mean and what more can you tell us about it?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Well, this has been something the EU has been discussing for several years now, but it sort of was brought to fore around 2020.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And it's around the EU's way of having its own autonomy when it comes to security and defence so the EU wouldn't have to rely on the United States when it needs to defend itself and its citizens.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And of course, that has been very much seen or highlighted given the relationship the EU had with the United States under the Trump administration where the partnership essentially was diminished all but completely.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Of course it's been revived under Joe Biden but the EU doesn't see that it can rely on the US for intelligence and for a partnership every single year or every single four years if there's a new president to the White House. So this has been something that the French have been pushing, but also particularly pushing now because they have the presidency of the European Council. Stefan?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: All right, Shona Marin, Brussels, thank you very much for this update.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: No matter what sanctions may look like for Russia, those imposed so far have taken its toll on the country. Moscow's central bank cautiously reopened bond trading on the Moscow exchange today. The bank has been closed since February 25th, the day Russian troops entered Ukraine. And for more on the impact on the Russian economy, let's cross to our correspondent Galina Polonskaya in Paris. Thank you for joining Galina and good to see you so as the EU is thinking about Russia's oil embargo what does Russia say and what would that mean to them hello Stefan well that would mean a huge colossal hit for the russian budget as analysts say because it depends a lot on those revenues so the kremlin is now talking about the consequences for the rest of the world that's what the vladimir putin's spokesman spoke about today when he was asked about any possible uh oil embargo coming from Europe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And he said that it would hit the energy market.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: But first of all, Europe's energy balance.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And today in the parliament, we've had the deputy chairman of Russia's government who was talking about a price for a barrel of oil.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: If something like this would happen, he said that it would cost $500 per barrel.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: if something like this would happen he said that it would cost 500 dollars per barrel said that russia is doing everything to diversify its supplies to sell it to other buyers and he said quote oil is not only a gas pipeline but also tankers but uh things are not that easy obviously i've spoke today stefan with a mikhail krutinin. He's a Russian oil and gas expert.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And he explained to me what would happen and how huge it would be for Russia's budget, how huge it would be for Russia's economy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: If such an embargo arises and they stop buying Russian oil in Europe, in the European Union, then this will be a colossal blow to the Russian economy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: in Europe, in the European Union, then this will be a colossal blow to the Russian economy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We see that 27% officially goes to the federal budget from oil somewhere, but in reality it is more than 60%, because you have to take into account taxes on profits from oil campaigns and many other taxes. But it is difficult to imagine a complete embargo in Europe for several reasons. Firstly, some European countries, they now cannot do without Russian oil.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: They simply do not have other sources of it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Mr. Krutikin also told me that if such an embargo happens, Russia could indeed retaliate and, for example, cut the gas to Germany.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: We have already heard such warnings coming from the kremlin in while international and energy agency reported that oil markets could lose three million barrels

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: per day of russian oil already starting from april because of the sanctions that have already been introduced and the buyers reluctance as mr krutikhin uh described described this he said that buyers do not want to buy russian oil because of the reputational reasons galena there have been other developments as well for instance uh concerning a russian court which acknowledged um extremist content on um media can you tell us more about this yes exactly so uh Facebook and Instagram those main platforms of meter have been already banned in Russia for several days but today Moscow court declared them extremists and that would mean a total ban and everything which is posted there or any sign of a logo on the cafe would mean a link with an extremist organization and any advertisement there as well so now the lawyers are trying to understand what would that uh mean because of course users could use VPN and go on Facebook and Instagram but lawyers say that it would it could be really a serious risk if a police finds Facebook or Instagram app on a mobile smartphone of a protester for example and it would exactly mean a link with an extremist organization so the kremlin is really controlling the message right now of what is happening in ukraine and is using internet differently let's say there are already groups in russian social media which are trying to target those who are stepping out against the war all right right, Galina Polonskaya, thank you very much for these insights.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Rescue efforts are underway after a plane with 132 people on board

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: crashed in southern China early Monday morning.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: There is still no word of survivors after the China Eastern Airlines plane dropped thousands of meters in just three minutes the plane was traveling from kunming to the industrial center of guangzhou and the crash caused a forest fire that could be seen by nasa satellite images the man who stabbed and killed british lawmaker damid amos last year is on trial in london central criminal court during opening statements the prosecution said 26-year-old Ali Harbi Ali was a committed Islamist terrorist who spent years plotting potential attacks on lawmakers, including the deadly attack on Amess.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Ali denies charges of murder and preparing acts of terrorism.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: False claims have continued to spread, linking Ukrainian President Zelensky with Nazism.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Let's find out more from Matthew in the Cube.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Well, Stefan, when addressing the nation, or indeed foreign parliaments, Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky has often been seen wearing a green shirt.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And particular attention has been on the symbol that is emblazoned on the front of that t-shirt. It is a symbol that is also seen on the website of the Ukrainian Defence Ministry and on the country's coat of arms.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: However, online pro-Kremlin users have been associating that symbol with another one, the iron cross that was worn by German Nazi soldiers during the Second World War. At the start of the invasion, Russian President Vladimir Putin described it as, quote, a special military operation to denazify Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And therefore, online users have been sharing these kind of misleading claims to link Zelensky with neo-Nazism and feed that Kremlin narrative.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But those allegations are false.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The cross symbol is used widely by a number of institutions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: For example, in the United Kingdom, where it is the symbol of the Victoria Cross, the highest honour that can be awarded.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And what's more, if you go onto the website of the Ukrainian army, you can see that that cross symbol is displayed on the coat of arms of at least three different sections.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Zelensky, as president, is the supreme commander-in-chief of Ukraine's army and that therefore indicates why he would be wearing that symbol. The symbol of the cross itself does not have any direct links to neo-Nazism.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: It's important to state, Stefan, that this kind of misinformation is still spreading online, despite the fact it has long been debugged by fact-checkers. Zelensky, who is of course Jewish himself and pictured here at a Holocaust memorial, has not been wearing a neo-Nazi symbol when he's been addressing the Ukrainian public or foreign parliaments. All right, Matthew in the Cube, thank you very much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: In 2016, when Nazanin Zaghari-Radcliffe left to visit her parents in Iran, she expected to stay two weeks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: But it would be six years before she set foot on British soil again, having been detained on charges of espionage by Iranian authorities.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Now the British and Iranian National is speaking out against UK politicians, saying they should have rescued her years ago.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Anna Ulla has the story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Nearly six years after she was detained in Iran, Nazanin Zaghari-Radcliffe is back in Britain, reunited with her husband and now eight-year-old daughter.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Speaking publicly for the first time since her return, the British-Iranian dual national slammed the British government for not doing enough to bring her home.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: I was told many, many times that, oh, we're going to get you home. That never happened.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So there was a time that I felt like, do you know what, I'm not even going to trust you, because I have been told many, many times that I'm going to be taken home. But that never happened. I mean, how many foreign secretaries does it take for someone to come out? Five. What's happened now should have happened six years ago.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The UK negotiated Zaghari Radcliffe's release last week, along with another British hostage, Anousheh Ashouri. But Zaghari Radcliffe said she could not fully celebrate as long as other dual nationals, including British American Morad Tabaz, were still detained in Iran.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: I believe that the meaning of freedom is never going to be complete until such time that all of us who are unjustly detained in Iran are reunited with our families.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Zaghari Radcliffe was arrested and detained in April 2016 while visiting her parents in Iran.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The government accused her of plotting to overthrow the regime and spread propaganda.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Charges she denies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Anca Ula, Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: We'll leave you with a no comment from Valencia, where locals celebrated the end of the Fallas Festival, a religious holiday and a gathering to ring in the arrival of spring.
